comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Miss De Acosta (at left) could be en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_de_Acosta Her memoir, Here Lies the Heart, [ books.google.com/books?id=oDtaAAAAMAAJ ] mentions a Vouletti Proctor. Photo at www.houseofproctor.org/genealogy/showmedia.php?mediaID=21248 could match woman at right. Neither of these possibly identifying pictures is a certain match.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%207/New%20York%20NY%20Times/... mentions Kathryn T. Motley, Mercedes De Acosta, and Vouletti Proctor as being among the "younger set" at a carnival -- in March 1915.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Of the noted de Acosta sisters, Aida and Rita were married before 1915, which probably leaves Mercedes as the "Miss" here. There are several close-up photos of sisters Joy Proctor and Vouletti Proctor Brown in the 1920s here: sandpond.org/1920s.htm

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Candidates for the Misses Stillman and Whitney are Lisa Stillman and Prudence Whitney, who were debutantes about the same time as Kathryn/Catherine/Katharine Motley ( I find all spellings and don't know if the are actually the same person) See NYT of December 4, 1909 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70C17FD3F5C15738...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Press/... has Lisa Stillman, Kathryn Motley, and Mercedes de Acosta all attending the same dance. NYT of January 20, 1910 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3071EFA3E5D11738... has Lisa Stillman as "debutante daughter of Mrs. Joseph F. Stillman" NYT of December 11, 1909 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40911FC395D12738... "Mrs. W. Henry Moteley gave a reception at her residence, 578 Madison Avenue, yesterday, to introduce her daughter, Miss Kathryn Motley. Receiving with the debutante and her mother were the Misses Ursula W. Brown, Lisa Stillman ..."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Tribun... New York Tribune reports the marriage of Prudence Whitney in June 1914 in Rye, NY.. "Miss Prudence Whitney to Become Bride of Robert Mallory, Jr." So if this is a 1915 photo, perhaps the Miss Whitney is not Prudence. The marriage announcement did not list a sister among the bridemaids.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Another possible Miss Whitney is Flora Payne Whitney (1897-1986): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flora_Payne_Whitney She appears in several other LOC photos, albeit looking a bit younger than the Miss Whitney in this one. On the other hand, a few years can make a big difference. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2349967126/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2404815875/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3598148048/]
